Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I was finishing up a balayage on a first-time client when I noticed her frown in the mirror. She hesitated, then quietly said, “It’s a bit warmer than I expected.” My heart sank—I knew how important it was to make her feel heard and satisfied, especially as a new visitor. I started to apologize and explain how we could adjust the tone, but my phone buzzed urgently in my pocket. A message from my activist group flashed on the screen: “Police are blocking exits—need help coordinating safe routes NOW.” My mind raced. As a hairdresser, I needed to stay calm, reassure my client, and fix her colour. But as an activist, I was expected to act immediately, to help protect my friends and the cause I cared about. I felt my hands tremble, torn between the woman in my chair and the people in the streets, both counting on me in different ways.
